verses.verse: When you sit down to dine with a ruler, take careful note of what is before you.
Control yourself[b] if you are given to overindulgence.
Do not yearn for the ruler’s delicacies, for they are deceptive food.
Do not wear yourself out in the pursuit of wealth, and cease even to think about it.
When you fix your gaze upon it, it is gone before you realize it. For it suddenly sprouts wings and flies up to the sky like an eagle.
Do not dine with a stingy man or hanker for his delicacies.
For, like a hair, they will stick in your throat. “Eat and drink,” he will say to you, but he does not mean it in his heart.
You will vomit up the little you have eaten and find that your compliments have been wasted.
Do not waste your words on a fool who will only despise the wisdom of your comments.[e]
Do not move an ancient boundary stone or encroach on the lands of orphans.
For their redeemer is powerful, and he will take up their cause against you.
Apply your heart to instruction and your ears to words of knowledge.
Do not withhold discipline from a child; if you beat him with a rod, he will not die.
Rather, if you beat him with a rod, you will save him from the netherworld.[h]
My son, if your heart is wise, then my heart will be glad.
Also my innermost being will rejoice when your lips utter what is right.
Do not allow your heart to envy sinners, but always be zealous for the fear of the LORD;[i]
there truly is a future for you, and your hope will not be cut short.
Listen, my son, and be wise as you direct your heart along the right path.
Do not consort with drunkards[j] or be one of those who gorge themselves with meat.
For the drunkard and the glutton will become impoverished, and stupor will clothe them in rags.
Listen to your father who begot you, and do not despise your mother[k] when she is old.
Buy truth and do not sell it; this is wisdom, instruction, and understanding.
The father of a good man will rejoice; he who begets a wise son will delight in him.
May your father and mother be glad; may the one who bore you exult.
My son, pay attention to me and let your eyes delight in my ways.
For a prostitute is a deep well, and an adulteress is a narrow pit.
Such a woman lies in wait like a robber, and many are the men she deludes.
Who endures misery? Who endures remorse? Who has strife? Who has anxiety? Who becomes bruised without knowing the reason? Who has blackened eyes?
Those who linger over their wine too long, those who sample blended wines.
Do not note how red the wine is, how it sparkles in the cup, and how smoothly it goes down.
For in the end its bite is like that of a serpent or that of a poisonous viper.
Then your eyes will behold strange sights, and your heart will utter distorted words.
You will become like one sleeping at sea or clinging to the top of the mast.
You will say, “They struck me, but I was not hurt. They beat me, but I did not feel it. When will I awaken, so that I can seek another drink?”
